text: Introduction—the machine age
label: Title

text: THIS BOOK Was conceived and written in the late years of the Nineteen-
label: Paragraph

text: fifties, an epoch that has variously been called the Jet Age, the Detergent
label: Paragraph

text: Decade, the Second Industrial Revolution. Almost any label that identifies
label: Paragraph

text: anything worth identifying in the period will draw attention to some
label: Paragraph

text: aspect of the transformation of science and technology, for these transfor-
label: Paragraph

text: mations have powerfully affected human life, and opened up new paths of
label: Paragraph

text: choice in the ordering of our collective destiny. Our accession to almost
label: Paragraph

text: unlimited supplies of energy is balanced against the possibility of making
label: Paragraph

text: our planet uninhabitable, but this again is balanced, as we stand at the
label: Paragraph

text: threshold of space, by the growing possibility of quitting our island earth
label: Paragraph

text: and letting dawn roots elsewhere. Again, our explorations into the nature
label: Paragraph

text: of information have made it-possible, on the one hand, to set electronics to
label: Paragraph

text: work to take the drudgery out of routine thought, and on the other hand
label: Paragraph

text: to tailor human thinking to suit the needs of some narrow-minded power-
label: Paragraph

text: élite.
label: Paragraph

text: These, of course, are the grand prospects that affect economics, morality
label: Paragraph

text: and sociology, in the same remote and statistical way as did the perfection
label: Paragraph

text: of cavalry, the growth of feudal organisations, the rise of money economy.
label: Paragraph

text: But, unlike those developments of the past, which left the objects of daily
label: Paragraph

text: life, the hierarchy of the family and the structure of sociable intercourse
label: Title

text: almost untouched, the technical revolutions of our own time strike us with
label: Paragraph

text: infinitely greater force because the small things of life have been visibly
label: Paragraph

text: and audibly revolutionised as well.
label: Paragraph

text: Even a man who does not possess an electric razor is ikely—in the
label: Paragraph

text: Westernised world at least—to dispense some previously inconceivable
label: Paragraph

text: product, such as an aerosol shaving cream, from an equally unprecedented
label: Paragraph

text: pressurised container, and accept with equanimity the fact that he can
label: Paragraph

text: afford to throw away, regularly, cutting-edges that previous generations
label: Paragraph

text: would have nursed for years. Even a housewife who does not possess a
label: Paragraph

text: washing machine dispenses synthetic detergent from synthetic plastic
label: Title

text: packs on to synthetic fabrics whose quality and performance makes the
label: Paragraph

text: jeatously-guarded secrets of silk seer trivial. A teen-ager, curled up with a
label: Paragraph

text: a.
label: Paragraph

text: transistorised, printed-circuit radio, or boudoir gramophone, may hear a
label: Paragraph

text: music that literally did not exist before it was committed to tape, repro-
label: Paragraph

text: duced at a level of quality that riches could not have bought a decade or so
label: Paragraph

text: ago. The average automobile of today, running on such roads as have been
label: Paragraph

text: especially contrived for it, provides transport more sumptuous in vehicles
label: Paragraph

text: more gorgeous than palanquin-borne emperors knew how to desire.
label: Paragraph

text: Many technologies have contributed to this domestic revolution, but
label: Paragraph

text: most of therm make their point of impact on us in the form of small machines
label: Paragraph

text: —shavers, clippers and hair-dryers; radio, telephone, gramophone, tape
label: Paragraph

text: recorder and television; mixers, grinders, automatic cookers, washing
label: Paragraph

text: machines, refrigerators, vacuum cleaners, polishers. ...A housewife alone,
label: Paragraph

text: often disposes of more horse-power today than an industrial worker did at
label: Paragraph

text: the beginning of the century. This is the sense in which we live in a
label: Paragraph

text: Machine Age. We have lived in an Industrial Age for nearly a century and
label: Paragraph

text: a half now, and may well be entering a Second Industrial Age with the
label: Paragraph

text: current revolution in control mechanisms. But we have already entered the
label: Paragraph

text: Second Machine Age, the age of domestic electronics and synthetic chem-
label: Title

text: istry, and can look back on the First, the age of power from the mains and
label: Paragraph

text: the reduction of machines to human scale, as a period of the past,
label: Paragraph

text: Although the earhest stirrings of that First Machine Age must have
label: Paragraph

text: appeared with the availability of coal-gas for lighting and heating, the
label: Paragraph

text: mechanism of light and heat remained @ flame, as it had been from the
label: Paragraph

text: Stone Age onwards. Mains electricity made a decisive alteration here, one
label: Paragraph

text: of the most decisive in the history of domestic technology. In addition, it
label: Paragraph

text: brought small, woman-controlled machinery into the home, notably the
label: Paragraph

text: vacuum cleaner. Electrical techniques brought the telephone as well, and
label: Paragraph

text: for the first time domestic and sociable communication did not depend on
label: Paragraph

text: the sending of written or remembered messages. The portable typewriter
label: Paragraph

text: put a machine under the hands of poets, the first gramophones made music
label: Paragraph

text: a domestic service rather than a social ceremony.
label: Paragraph

text: Alt these machines are still with us in the Second Machine Age, supple-
label: Paragraph

text: mented and improved by more recent technological advances, but there is
label: Paragraph

text: a more than quantitative difference between the two ages. In the Second,
label: Paragraph

text: highly developed mass production methods have distributed electronic
label: Paragraph

text: devices and synthetic chemicals broadcast over a large part of society—
label: Paragraph

text: television, the symbolic machine of the Second Machine Age, hag be-
label: Paragraph

text: come a means of mass-communication dispensing popular entertainment.
label: Paragraph

text: In the First, however, only cmema was available to a broad public, whose
label: Paragraph

text: home life was otherwise barely touched and it was in upper middle-class
label: Paragraph

text: homes that the First Machine Age made its greatest impact, the homes that
label: Paragraph

text: could afford these new, convenient and expensive aids to gracious living,
label: Paragraph

text: the homes that tend to breed architects, painters, poets, journalists, the
label: Paragraph

text: creators of the myths and symbols by which a culture recognises itself.
label: Paragraph

text: Thus, it was into the hands of an élite, rather than the masses, that the
label: Paragraph

text: symbolic machine of that First Machine Age was delivered, the automobile,
label: Paragraph

text: It was more than a symbol of power, it was also, for most of that éite,
label: Paragraph

text: a heady taste of a new kind of power.) One of the uncommented curiosities of
label: Paragraph

text: the early part of the Industrial Age is that, in spite of its massive depen-
label: Paragraph

text: dence on mechanical power, few of its éfite, if any, had any personal experi-
label: Paragraph

text: ence of controlling that power. They could buy the use of it with money,
label: Paragraph

text: and ride in its great ships and famous expresses, but they did not dirty
label: Paragraph

text: their hands with the controls, That was left to a separate, working-class
label: Paragraph

text: élite of ships’ engineers, engine-drivers and so forth, who retired into the
label: Paragraph

text: middie-classes when their service was complete.
label: Paragraph

text: But, with the coming of purchasable motor-cars, it became possible, and
label: Paragraph

text: fashionable, for the opinion-forming classes to own and personally control
label: Paragraph

text: units of motive power of up to sixty, or even a hundred horse-power.
label: Paragraph

text: Although they brought ever into this new situation certain horse-and-
label: Paragraph

text: groom social usages, the psychological effect was a revolution that struck
label: Paragraph

text: deep. Many of thern were clearly aware that the men who made and serviced
label: Paragraph

text: their cars were of an utterly different breed and mind to those who had bred
label: Paragraph

text: and cared for their horses. Over and above this, the jump in speed from a
label: Paragraph

text: spanking twenty-five miles an hour to the roaring sixties, with the magic
label: Paragraph

text: century an ever approaching goal for the really rich and determined,
label: Paragraph

text: brought in changes of experience that were qualitative, not merely quanti-
label: Paragraph

text: tative—the dynamics of a fast-moving car are different in kind to the
label: Paragraph

text: dynamics of even a race-horse. The Man Muitiplied by the Motor, to use
label: Paragraph

text: Marinetti’s phrase, was a different kind of man to the horse-and-buggy men
label: Paragraph

text: who had ruled the world since the time of Alexander the Great.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: When Gropius, in the Bauhaus Proclamation of 1919, talked of handicrafts
label: Paragraph

text: he was, effectively, talking to himself. His re-establishment as one of the
label: Paragraph

text: leaders of Modern design after about 1923 was as the head of a school
label: Paragraph

text: devoted to Machine Age architecture and the design of machine products,
label: Paragraph

text: employing 2a Machine Age aesthetic that had been worked out by other
label: Paragraph

text: men in other places,
label: Paragraph

text: Naturally that Machine Age aesthetic was not an entirely new creation
label: Paragraph

text: —the men who wrought it came to the First Machine Age bowed down with
label: Paragraph

text: two-thousand years’ culture on their backs, but the very minimum of the
label: Paragraph

text: new mental equipment needed to handle their new environment. At one
label: Paragraph

text: extreme, the Futurists proposed to dump their cultural load, and rush
label: Paragraph

text: forward equipped only with a new sensibility; at the other extreme, men
label: Paragraph

text: like Perret and Garnier in France felt that the new should be, in Paul
label: Paragraph

text: Valéry's phrase, subject to the old, or at least the outlines of the old.
label: Paragraph

text: Between Futurist dynamism and this Academic caution the theory and
label: Paragraph

text: design of the architecture of the First Machine Age were evolved, Whether
label: Paragraph

text: those theories, and that architecture were what we, looking back from the
label: Paragraph

text: Second Machine Age, would regard as proper, or even adequate, to their
label: Paragraph

text: situation, is a question which will be held over until the last chapter, after
label: Paragraph

text: the events and theories of the period have been described, Nevertheless,
label: Paragraph

text: while we yet lack a body of theory proper to our own Machine Age, we are
label: Paragraph

text: still free-wheeling along with the ideas and aesthetics left over from the first,
label: Paragraph

text: The reader may therefore, at any turn, find among these relics of a past
label: Paragraph

text: as economically, socially, and technologically dead as the city-states of
label: Paragraph

text: Greece, ideas that he is using every day of his life. Should he do so, may
label: Paragraph

text: he ask himself two things; firstly, are any of his ideas as up-to-date as he
label: Paragraph

text: thinks them to be, this is the Second Machine Age not the First; and
label: Paragraph

text: secondly, how out-moded in truth are the ideas he dismisses as mere
label: Paragraph

text: fashions of the Jazz Decades, for one Machine Age is more like another
label: Paragraph

text: Machine Age than any other epoch the world has ever known. The cultural
label: Paragraph

text: revolution that took place around 1912 has been superseded, but it has not
label: Paragraph

text: been reversed,

text: WHILE A SERIES OF revolutionary gestures around rgro, largely connected
label: Paragraph

text: with the Cubist and Futurist movements, were the main point of departure
label: Paragraph

text: for the development of Modern architecture, there were also a number of
label: Paragraph

text: particular predisposing causes that helped to guide the mainstream of
label: Paragraph

text: development into the channels through which it flowed in the Twenties,
label: Paragraph

text: These predisposing causes were all of nineteenth-century origin, and may
label: Paragraph

text: be loosely grouped under three heads: firstly, the sense of an architect’s
label: Paragraph

text: responsibility to the society in which he finds himself, an idea of largely
label: Paragraph

text: English extraction, from Pugin, Ruskin, and Morris, which was summed up
label: Paragraph

text: in an organisation founded in 1907, the Deutscher Werkbund: secondly,
label: Paragraph

text: the Rationalist, or structural approach to architecture, again of English
label: Paragraph

text: extraction, from Willis, but elaborated in France by Viollet-le-Duc, and
label: Paragraph

text: codified in Auguste Choisy’s magisterial Histoire at the very end of the
label: Paragraph

text: century, though the parailel tradition in Germany has no major exponent
label: Paragraph

text: after Gottfried Semper; and, thirdly, the tradition of academic instruction,
label: Paragraph

text: world wide in distribution, but owing most of its energy and authority to
label: Paragraph

text: the Ecole des Beaux-Arts in Paris, from which there emerged, just after the
label: Paragraph

text: turn of the century, Julien Guadet’s compendious summary of his course of
label: Paragraph

text: professorial lectures—though again no equivalent work appeared ia Ger-
label: Paragraph

text: many at that time.
label: Paragraph

text: The attitude of those who were to become the masters of Modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture to these traditions from the past was apt to be equivocal. The
label: Paragraph

text: Werkbund and its members were the object of suspicien in some quarters,
label: Paragraph

text: though most of the younger architects accepted the moral imperatives
label: Paragraph

text: bound up in it. The Rationalist attitude was held in high regard, yet
label: Paragraph

text: effectively repudiated by most of them, and the academic tradition was
label: Paragraph

text: generally vilified, yet many of the ideas it embodied were taken over by
label: Paragraph

text: them.
label: Paragraph

text: The last circumstance makes the evaluation of Guadet’s contribution to
label: Paragraph

text: modern theory dithcult to assess. Those who rejected the academic disci-
label: Paragraph

text: pline did so because they felt it to be hostile to their conception of archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture, which they held to be functional, scientific and divorced from
label: Paragraph

text: stylistic considerations, Yet, on the evidence of his five volumes of Eléments
label: Paragraph

text: et Théortes de? Architecture, Guadet—the very embodiment of the academy
label: Paragraph

text: —was as functional, scientific and un-stylistic as they. Conversely, they tn
label: Paragraph

text: their turn, while repudiating the ‘false standards of the academies’,
label: Paragraph

text: accepted many academic ideas without knowing where they had come from.
label: Paragraph

text: Thus Gropius in 1923, having criticised the academies for not nurturing
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic science, goes on in the succeeding paragraphs to make use of a
label: Paragraph

text: number of aesthetic concepts that resemble those of French academic
label: Paragraph

text: origin.?

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: silences that were observed m academic teachmg on subjects held to be

text: too obvious or too sacred for discussion. On the first count, one must note

label: Paragraph

text: But there is a new ‘element’ among Scott's four—Space. This was not
label: Paragraph

text: being discussed in architectural circles in France at the time, neither with-
label: Paragraph

text: in the Beaux-Arts curriculum as recorded by Guadet, nor by Choisy and his
label: Paragraph

text: followers. Choisy uses the word espace to mean an area to be spanned by
label: Paragraph

text: an arch or covered by a roof, and where we might nowadays use the word
label: Paragraph

text: ‘space’ te indicate an unbuilt volume within a building he is more tnclined
label: Paragraph

text: to use la vide. By Space, Scott means, effectively, Raum, with most of the over-
label: Paragraph

text: tones that the word had acquired in German aesthetics, and he himself had
label: Paragraph

text: avowedly taken it over from the writings of Theodor Lipps, along with the
label: Paragraph

text: theory of Einfithiung.
label: Paragraph

text: Lippsian theory seems to have been common currency in the Anglo-
label: Paragraph

text: Florentine circle in which he moved (Berenson, Vernon Lee et af.}? and it
label: Paragraph

text: is used by Scott to give a show of objectivity to the extremely solipsistic
label: Paragraph

text: attitude he is taking up, viz., that architecture affects us by its mimic cor-
label: Paragraph

text: respondence with human attitudes and actions. His position depends, on
label: Paragraph

text: examimation, on a kind of pun on the word ‘Humanist’, which he uses
label: Paragraph

text: indiscriminately to refer either to the world of humane learning, or to the
label: Paragraph

text: projection of human sentiments into the forms of architecture. This
label: Paragraph

text: double-entendre appears to be quite unconscious, but it is upon it, and no-
label: Paragraph

text: thing else, that his theory of Renaissance architecture as an art of pure
label: Paragraph

text: form, pure taste and pure pleasure is founded. Presumably the material,
label: Paragraph

text: from which Professor Wittkower later developed his entirely different view
label: Paragraph

text: of Renaissance architecture as an art of symbolic form, was also available to
label: Paragraph

text: Scott had he wanted to use it, but, under the academic dispensation which
label: Paragraph

text: set symbolic and narrative values aside, he could explain his liking for
label: Paragraph

text: Renaissance architecture only by assuming it to be meaningless at any but
label: Paragraph

text: the empathetic level.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: innovation. The introduction was not seminal, but it retains its interest
label: Paragraph

text: as an illustration of a process which must have happened elsewhere, though
label: Paragraph

text: not explicitly. The change-over from the Lippsian idea of space, as felt
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: THE YEAR 1907 must appear, in retrospect, a decisive one for German (and,
label: Paragraph

text: by that token, international} architecture. If no new themes are introduced
label: Paragraph

text: inte architectural thought, attitudes toward certain contemporary problems
label: Title

text: were as resolutely taken up as they were, a little later, by the Futurists, and
label: Paragraph

text: what is more—were shortly translated inte practice, That is to say,
label: Paragraph

text: discussion and exposition among architects and those connected with design
label: Title

text: were primarily devoted to evolving programmes and organisations for im-
label: Paragraph

text: mediate action, and not to the formulation of bodies of encyclopaedic
label: Paragraph

text: theory in the manner of Choisy or Guadet. There was indeed a parallel
label: Paragraph

text: current of pure intellectual speculation about the aesthetics of architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: descending from Lipps and producing one of its classics in Worringer’s
label: Paragraph

text: Abstraktion und Eimnfiihlung of 1908, but there seems to have been no impor-
label: Paragraph

text: tant mingling of the two streams of thought—the men of action tapped the
label: Paragraph

text: Lippsian stream at source, not at Worrmger.
label: Paragraph

text: The heart-theme of the practical body of thought was the problem of
label: Paragraph

text: mechanism—or rather, the relationship of architecture, as an art of design,
label: Paragraph

text: to mechanical production at all its phases, from the factory work-hall to
label: Paragraph

text: the advertising of the finished product. This relationship was scrutinised
label: Paragraph

text: most closely at two critical points: the aesthetics of engineering construc-
label: Paragraph

text: tion, and the aesthetics of product design. To take the first point first,
label: Paragraph

text: leaders of German architectural thought, like the Italian Futurists, de-
label: Paragraph

text: plored the application of art-work to engimeering structures, but whereas
label: Paragraph

text: the Futurists intended to conjure an aesthetic out of machinery and engin-
label: Paragraph

text: eertng, the Germans hoped to conjure some aesthetics into them,
label: Paragraph

text: Already, therefore, in 1907, the Verband Deutscher Architekten- und Ingenieur-
label: Paragraph

text: tereing was challenging expert opinion on this point: How shall we force up the
label: Paragraph

text: importance of aesthetic considerations in engineering construction to a higher
label: Paragraph

text: level than at present.
label: Paragraph

text: Phrased thus, as a sort of collision between two separate entities, aesthetics
label: Paragraph

text: and engineering, the problem tended to indicate two equally separate
label: Paragraph

text: answers, a3 Lindner and Steinmetz go on to record
label: Paragraph

text: We soon saoived at the conchuion that eny solution for cur new situation
label: Paragraph

text: involved the discovery of a new, appropriate and heartfelt mode of expression.
label: Paragraph

text: The architecture of the styles having broken down, everybody changed their
label: Paragraph

text: aim and began to shoot in different directions. Some preached Pure Functional
label: Paragraph

text: Art (Reine Zweckkunst) while others saw the ideal in untrametled artistic crea-
label: Paragraph

text: tion ‘each according to his own powers’ finding new forme for new problema.
label: Paragraph

text: This latter paragraph identifies, perhaps unwittingly, a basic division in the
label: Paragraph

text: work of the years immediately after 1907. Lindner and Steinmetz associate
label: Paragraph

text: ‘new forms for new problems’ with “untramelled artistic creation’ and not
label: Paragraph

text: with ‘Pure Functional Art’ and it is to be noted that those most closely
label: Paragraph

text: associated with the pure service of function—Behrens, Muthesius, Mies
label: Paragraph

text: van der Rohe and Gropius (with one notable exception’}—were not for-
label: Paragraph

text: mally inventive, while the Individualists, later termed Expressionists, of
label: Paragraph

text: that generation in Germany—Poelzig, Berg, Marx, Stoffregen—were
label: Paragraph

text: among the most fertile creative minds in their profession at that time, and
label: Paragraph

text: the most vigorous continuers of the spirit of the English Free architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: It should be emphasised here that this division of practical method does
label: Paragraph

text: not imply, at that time, any notable division of theoretical approach—that
label: Paragraph

text: did not appear until after 1922, when Zweckkunst finally acquired a formal
label: Paragraph

text: language of its own—nor any difference of organisational loyalty, All these
label: Paragraph

text: architects were connected with the Werkbund, and the two whom it is
label: Paragraph

text: most customary to contrast; Hans Poelzig and Peter Behrens, both en-
label: Paragraph

text: joyed the support of Hermann Muthestus, the Werkbund’s founder.
label: Paragraph

text: But, in any case, it was events connected with the Werkbund and with
label: Paragraph

text: Peter Behrens that made 1907 a decisive year, rather than the beginnings of
label: Paragraph

text: a stylistic diviston among the progressive German architects. For it was in
label: Paragraph

text: 1907 that Behrens joined AEG (Allgemeine Electricitdtspesellschaft) and
label: Paragraph

text: Mauthesius founded the Deutscher Werkbund. The two events are related,
label: Paragraph

text: if not connected, and are the two faces of the same coin—a rapprochement
label: Paragraph

text: between creative designers and productive industry, in which industry was
label: Paragraph

text: a more willing participant than the designers.
label: Paragraph

text: The foundation of the Werkbund took place ia the teeth of some fairly
label: Paragraph

text: spirited opposition from the ‘establishment’ of the German Arts and

text: Indeed, this central bridged section of the Bauhaus building casts light

text: on aspects of Gropius that are at variance with the commonly held views

text: of him. The bridge was not forced on him by topography (as the great

label: Paragraph

text: was not usable until some time after the buildings were completed. The
label: Paragraph

text: decision to arrange the circulation and the buildings in this way appears to
label: Paragraph

text: have been an almost abstract decision made on an ideal terrain. Almost
label: Paragraph

text: abstract, rather than completely abstract, because behind the architec-
label: Paragraph

text: tonic decision lies a rather surprising social one—the road that divides the
label: Paragraph

text: site also divides the buildings into two distinct halves in spite of the bridge;

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: of snobbery’ had once more been erected between artist and craftsman.

text: victim to an old-established exasperation of the propagandists
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: But the victory of the new architecture was real and international—
label: Paragraph

text: sufficiently so for 1928 to witness the first attacks on it as an ‘International
label: Paragraph

text: Style’, for in that year Alexander von Senger published his Krisis der
label: Paragraph

text: Architektur, directed against Modern architecture as a whole, but based
label: Paragraph

text: entirely on quotations from Le Corbusier’s books and from L'Esprit
label: Paragraph

text: Neuveau, which is described as
label: Paragraph

text: . +. this neo-Jacobin review, Le Corbusier's organ, the synthesis of Russian,
label: Paragraph

text: German and Austrian tendencies, is furthermore, nothing but a disguised
label: Paragraph

text: Bolshevik propaganda magazine.
label: Paragraph

text: The mainstream of Modern architecture had found its International Style,
label: Paragraph

text: and so had its opponents, for whom von Senger’s tone and tactics were to
label: Paragraph

text: become the norm. But the attitude of the numerous German books that
label: Paragraph

text: appeared after Weissenhof is not defensive, and their aim is to consolidate
label: Paragraph

text: the victory of the new style by effecting broad surveys of its materials, its
label: Paragraph

text: history, its aesthetics. In this! context, Ludwig Hilberseimer stands out
label: Paragraph

text: for his industry, if for no other reason, and is one of the most charac-
label: Paragraph

text: teristic figures of the epoch. His career, to this date, had not been outstand-
label: Paragraph

text: ingly busy or successful in architecture, but now, under the aegis of Hannes
label: Paragraph

text: Meyer, he founded a town-planning department at the Bauhaus, and in two
label: Paragraph

text: years produced four books that give a remarkably full coverage of the
label: Paragraph

text: Modern Movement as it then understood itself,
label: Paragraph

text: In one of them he surveyed the new architecture as a movement covering
label: Paragraph

text: mest of Europe, Internationale Neue Baukunst, which illustrated the work
label: Paragraph

text: of some seventy European architects (and four Americans), and proved his
label: Paragraph

text: judgement to be remarkably sure—vyery few of the architects whose work
label: Paragraph

text: he included have subsequently dropped out of professional esteem, and
label: Paragraph

text: in at feast one case—that of Sant’ Eha—subsequent re-appraisals have fully
label: Paragraph

text: justified his inclusion. Some of his other choices have proven almost
label: Paragraph

text: clairvoyant: Aiberto Sartoris and the Figini-Pollini partnership had hardly
label: Paragraph

text: a building to their credit at the time that Hilberseimer’s book was written.
label: Paragraph

text: Two of the other books he wrote at this time were surveys of particular
label: Paragraph

text: building types—using that term fairly loosely, to cover both Hallenbauten,
label: Paragraph

text: which dealt with auditoria, markets, etc. and Gresstadi-~Architektur which
label: Paragraph

text: surveyed public and semi-public buildings of a metropolitan scale. His
label: Paragraph

text: fourth book, and the most interesting of this group, deals with a particular
label: Paragraph

text: material, concrete.
label: Paragraph

text: Its title, Beton als Gestalter, gives a false impression of it, and suggests
label: Paragraph

text: that it belongs to a current of thought which was becoming increasingly
label: Paragraph

text: prevalent at this time, tending to interpret the International Style in purely
label: Paragraph

text: Rationalist terms, as the product of the materials and techniques employed.
label: Paragraph

text: Lissitsky may well have started this tendency in German-speaking circles,
label: Paragraph

text: for Hannes Meyer who took it into the Bauhaus had come under his in-
label: Paragraph

text: fluence, and it is noteworthy that the young Italian architects who formed
label: Paragraph

text: the like-thinking Mocitmento Italiano per l' Architettura Razionaie had also
label: Paragraph

text: come under Constructivist influence. It is also noteworthy that they were
label: Paragraph

text: not anti-Traditionalists, and this neo-Rationalist movement in general
label: Paragraph

text: found considerable reinforcement in the past, as in such studies of the
label: Paragraph

text: nineteenth century as Giedion's Bauen in Frankreich, which will be dis-
label: Paragraph

text: cussed later,
label: Paragraph

text: But Berlin played no great part in this development, which was largely
label: Paragraph

text: the work of ‘provincials’ from Switzerland, Italy, and the Anglo-Saxon
label: Paragraph

text: countries, Though Berlin writers had plenty to say about the new materials
label: Paragraph

text: at this time their tone was not Rationalistic, Thus, in Gias im Bau und
label: Paragraph

text: als Gebrauchsgegenstand, Artur Korn, whose architecture at this time had
label: Paragraph

text: taken a very tough, almost CG, quality, nevertheless writes of glass in an
label: Paragraph

text: almost poetic tone, laying particular stress on its aesthetic qualities. Indeed,
label: Paragraph

text: his book begins with an almost Scheerbartian apotheosis of mediaeval
label: Paragraph

text: stained glass, and then goes on
label: Paragraph

text: Nothing has been lost of the riches of these earlier creations, but it has been
label: Paragraph

text: reworked in new materials for new functions, A new world of glass has been
label: Paragraph

text: opened that concedes nothing to the windows of the Gothic world in beauty.
label: Paragraph

text: But we have secured a great advance over them . . . in making an independent
label: Paragraph

text: glass skin. No more wali and window, even though the window mpght be the
label: Paragraph

text: dominant part-—this window is the wal! itself, this wail is itself the window.
label: Paragraph

text: And therewith a development is consummated, something absolutely new over
label: Paragraph

text: and above al} that the past can show: the denial of the outer wall that for
label: Paragraph

text: thousands of years had to be made of solid materials—stone, wood or some-
label: Paragraph

text: thing similar. in this new dispensation the outer wail no tonger makes itself
label: Paragraph

text: VISIBLE.
label: Paragraph

text: The intericr spatial depths, the form-giving structural frame are in evidence,
label: Paragraph

text: appearing through the glass wall which itself is only hinted at, only barely to
label: Paragraph

text: be appreciated through reflected light, distortion and mirror effects.
label: Paragraph

text: And therewith appears the truly unique quality of glass compared to all materiela
label: Paragraph

text: hitherto in use: It is there and it is not there.
label: Paragraph

text: It is the great mystery membrane, delicate and strong at the same tire.
label: Paragraph

text: The words ‘there and not there’ are to be interpreted in more than one
label: Paragraph

text: sense, for he cites exarmples of transparency (the Bauhaus), reflectivity
label: Paragraph

text: (Mies’s glass towers) and of the use of non-reflecting glass as an invisible
label: Paragraph

text: barrier against the weather (a shop designed by himself and his partner
label: Paragraph

text: Konrad Weitzmann). But his attitude, if poetically inclined, remains
label: Paragraph

text: practical: he does not philosophise.
label: Paragraph

text: Hilberseimer does; and the introduction to Beten als Gestalter is a
label: Paragraph

text: reflective essay on the relationship of architecture as an art to sctence and
label: Paragraph

text: technology. His opening paragraph rejects at once both the Rationalist

text: As early as 1927, Fuller had advanced, in his Dymaxion House project, a

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: nology were interrupted, those processes of change and renovation that, as
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: know it today, and bringing both research and mass-production to a stap.
label: Paragraph

text: Whether or not the enforcement of norms and types by such a conscious
label: Paragraph

text: manoeuvre would be good for the human race, is a problem that does not
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: built in a Machine Age, and expressed an attitude to machinery—in the
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph
